steps.text: Today, we're diving into the remarkable story of Dorothy Vaughan, a pioneering mathematician and programmer at NASA.
Dorothy Vaughan began her career at NASA during World War II, in a time when computation was done manually.
She worked at the Langley Research Center where she became one of the most respected "human computers" of her time.
Despite the challenges of segregation, Dorothy excelled and eventually led the West Area Computing unit, an all-black and all-female team.
With the advent of electronic computers, she foresaw the need to learn programming, mastering FORTRAN and teaching others.
Here, we see Dorothy Vaughan teaching a group of eager women in a bustling NASA office, surrounded by mathematical charts and early computer equipment.
Dorothy Vaughan's legacy paved the way for future generations of women and minorities in STEM fields.

full_story: Dorothy Vaughan was a trailblazer in the field of mathematics and computer programming. She began working at NASA during World War II, a time when all calculations were done manually by a team of "human computers." Despite the era's racial segregation, she excelled at the Langley Research Center and became the first African-American woman to be promoted as a head of personnel. She led the West Area Computing unit, which was composed of African-American women. With the introduction of electronic computers, Dorothy saw the potential and importance of computers in scientific research. She became proficient in FORTRAN, one of the earliest programming languages, and taught many others as well. Her work laid the foundation for future generations of women and minorities in STEM fields.
